forumNotes.author: Stasheck
forumNotes.content:
Hi everyone,  

I'm currently on a quest in developing Ultimate Universal USB Boot/Install Drive ™®© ;-)  

I'm using grub2 (1.97b4), and memdisk (loaded via grub2). I haven't found a way to chainload grub4dos from grub2 - so if someone knows how to do it, tell me please :-)  

Also note that I need this pendrive to:  
- have only a single partition (it's easier to remove/add things this way)  
- be based on NTFS (so I can have files bigger than 4 GB \& still be able to run Windows installers off it)  

What I already achieved:  
- I'm able to boot a couple of Linux distros (in fact it's only important for me to boot Ubuntu, Debian and CentOS)  
- I'm able to boot a number of "utility" distros and tools (Parted Magic, RIPLinux, Clonezilla)  

What else do I want:  
- to be able to run multiple different Windows installations  

I need:  
- Windows 7 x86  
- Windows 7 x64  
- Windows 2K8 Server  
- Windows XP Pro  
- Windows XP Home  
- Windows 2K3 Server  

Now, as I found out reading this forum, it's impossible to have multiple NT6.x installers on a single disk - which is a shame. Also, I know that one can run NT5.x installer from DOS mode, but I'm not sure how to boot plain DOS with NTFS support from grub2.  

I'm quite willing to create pre-install images of all these windows versions, but I've never done it before, so:  
- what's the best way to do this  
- are they going to be universal? I mean, will I be able to install them on any machine?  
- from what I read, installing W7 from WinPE may result in it being on "D" instead of "C" drive - that's unacceptable for me  
- any hints?

forumNotes.author: Stasheck
forumNotes.content:
OK, I just found the solution to grub4dos from grub2 problem:  

linux16 /grub.exe  

does it :-)  

The rest - still waiting for bright ideas :-)

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> The rest - still waiting for bright ideas :-)
Ideas, yes. :smile:  
Bright, ***maybe*** . ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  

With all due respect, you started the wrong way. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  

> Also note that I ***need*** this pendrive to:  
> - have only a single partition (it's easier to remove/add things this way)  
> - be based on NTFS (so I can have files bigger than 4 GB \& still be able to run Windows installers off it)
There is NO ***need*** for a single partition, there***may be*** reasons, once evaluated the (supposed) "advantages" of having a single partition against the ***N*** problems you will have and workarounds and what not you will actually ***need*** to solve them.  

In other words. it seems to me like you are focusing more on the means than on the actual goal, this can make things very difficult or even impossible.  

Also, again IMHO, you fail to set the needed parameters, like amount of RAM on target machines, size/type of the USB drive, and so on.  

More generally, we have the advantage of having multiple partitions, why not using it? :smile:  

Also, since you have at least 6 "somethings" that will need grub4dos (or has now GRUB2 the "MS side" features grub4dos has? ![:huh:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/huh.png) - but then there would be no reason for grub4dos at all...:smile:), and listed a number of other "somethngs" that can be booted off grub4dos, the choice of using GRUB2 as "main" loader seems to me unjustified.  

Personally, I would use grub4dos as "main" loader and GRUB2 only for those thingies that actually need it (if any), in order to have on average more "direct" booting steps.  

Reading between the lines of this:  
[http://www.boot-land...?...ic=7138\&hl=](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=7138&hl= "External link")  

you may find some ideas to workaround the "single" partition limit.  

![:huh:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/huh.png)  
Wonko

forumNotes.author: Stasheck
forumNotes.content:
Yes, I'm aware that I chose the hard way :-) But that's how I do things - I like to make computers do my bidding, not me doing theirs.  

I believe that it's perfectly possible to achieve the goals I set for this project. And yes, probably having multiple partitions would make creating installers easiers - except that if I'd wanted to change eg Win7 x86 install to some linux distros, I'd effectively have to re-create the whole setup.  

About params:  
- I have 16 GB pendrive, but I want to be able to create such keys for other guys @work, they have some 4 and 8 GB sticks  
- Lowest mem would be 512 MB, but that's extreme - most of machines I have to deal with have \>1GB.  

I use GRUB2, because the project started when I wanted to explore it a bit :-)  

Also, I'm not sure if I need GRUB4DOS for anything: preinstal images are run from WinPE, aren't they? Nevertheless, I'm not sure if that's the way to go.
